review_title: Close knit and good work life balance
pros:
Nice colleagues who share goals and ways to reach them as a team
Good work life balance
cons: Minor bickering between the higher ups when they do not agree

pros: Junior Achievement is an outstanding organization that provides valuable educational resources to young people around the world. As a non-profit organization, Junior Achievement is dedicated to helping students develop financial literacy, entrepreneurship skills, and other important life skills that can help them succeed in the future. Working at Junior Achievement is a truly rewarding experience. The team is passionate and dedicated to their mission, and there is a real sense of camaraderie and support within the organization. Employees are encouraged to share their ideas and take on new challenges, which helps to foster a culture of innovation and continuous improvement. One of the great things about working at Junior Achievement is the opportunity to make a real difference in the lives of young people. Whether you're working directly with students in the classroom or supporting the organization behind the scenes, you can take pride in knowing that your work is helping to shape the future. Overall, I would highly recommend Junior Achievement to anyone who is passionate about education and making a positive impact on the world. If you're looking for a challenging and rewarding career, Junior Achievement is definitely a great place to work.
cons: None that come to mind

review_title: Non profit that wants to run as a corporate office.
job_title: Community Engagement Coordinator in Memphis, TN
pros: Mileage reimbursement, new building is nice.
cons: Will use micro aggressions, no interview process president hires who she knows, no hr although it is needed very badly. Would rather be friends with staff than have staff that are good at their jobs.

cons: I do not have any cons at this time.

pros:
My experience working here has been good. Okay, yeah, I butt heads with the management sometimes, but they’re not that bad really. My co-workers are AWESOME though. Honestly, they’re the glue that holds my sanity together. I mean, it’s not like I need other peoples’ support to function but having them around just makes work so much more fun. 
I feel like everyone likes to write about how they “learned so much” and “became better employees” but I feel like that would be the case anywhere you work, even if the company isn’t that great. That’s why I think it’s more important to talk about the people you work with and the effect that has on your day-to-day. 

All you need to know is that the people here are amazing, talented, incredible people and I’ll be loyal to this company for the next 5 decades because of them.
cons: I feel like I’ve said everything I need to say.

pros: JA USA has a great cultural and staff.
cons: I do not have any cons

review_title: I feel fulfilled and happy in my role
pros:
Junior Achievement USA is doing everything humanly possible to help bolster kids confidence and give them the tools they need to become their own bosses when they grow up. If 2020 has taught the human race anything, it’s that there is nothing more important than being in control of your job. You can’t get fired if you’re the boss. And that’s what makes keeps me going every day is just knowing that we’re giving these kids the chance at a more successful, stable, secure, and pandemic-proof future.

I love the work we do here and the impact is has had on thousands of kids lives. The work isn’t always easy and every day isn’t always fun, but everything we do here is always 100% worth it.
cons: How can I possibly write any cons to working at such an amazing company? If you’re looking for perfection, you won’t find it here. But also, you won’t find it anywhere. There’s no such thing as the perfect company. You just need to look for the company that’s the right fit for you. My advice is to find a mission you support and a company whose values line up with your own. Nothing else matters if you’re fulfilling your purpose.

review_title: A friend of mine referred me here
pros: I have a friend that referred me to work here. I wasn’t sure at first because I really didn’t want to work in the nonprofit sector. But I have to say I am very pleased so far. It’s not a typical nonprofit by any stretch of the imagination. We actually do a lot of good and aren’t taken advantage of in the slightest. I was expecting to be paid next to nothing and expected to give 200% and that hasn’t been the case.
cons: Nothing so far. I like it and I appreciate how enjoyable this whole experience has been.

job_title: Operations Manager in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: One of the best companies I’ve ever worked for. Employees at all levels of the organization are treated with respect. I’ve gained a significant amount of operations experience in the short time I’ve been here. Definitely more than I would have gotten anywhere else. Needless to say, people who are hungry for success are welcome here.
cons: Working for a non-profit isn’t easy. You need to be ready for what’s in store.

pros:
I worked for the Chicago region. We worked with many community businesses and some Fortune 500 companies so it was a great opportunity to network and make connections, which was helpful in finding potential job opportunities. I learned a lot about other industries by working with these companies. It opened doors. 

We also got to know many volunteers, teachers, and school administrators. I would say relationship building and connections was the best part of the job. 

I was in constantly going from place to place, schools, companies, etc. so it made the job interesting. That’s if you don’t like being in an office all day.
cons:
My specific area was in the outside suburbs of Chicago, and the area I had to cover was very large, and I would drive far sometimes. Although we were reimbursed for our mileage it was a lot of driving. 

The starting pay is minimal in my opinion. Minimum should be at LEAST $40k-$45k. 

Training was not structured and you learned on the job. Which was stressful. They should improve their training. I had to figure out many things on my own. Communication was also unorganized and lacking.

pros: I greatly enjoyed my time here. I learned a good deal, met many incredible people, and felt fulfilled and accomplished every single day. It was an eye-opening experience in more ways than one and one I won’t soon forget. I decided to take the knowledge we impart onto kids and put it to the test. I opened my own business and that’s the only reason I left. I’m excited for what my future holds and I know I have nothing but support and good feelings from my JA family.
cons: Like I said, the only reason I left was because I decided to finally put our teachings to the test. It’s one thing to tell kids how to be more entrepreneurial and another thing entirely to practice what you preach. It’s difficult, but I feel much more prepared for the challenges I’m facing as a business owner because of my time here and for that I’m eternally grateful.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Junior Achievement is a truly amazing company to work for. They know how to treat their staff, and more importantly how to keep them. I’ve been with the company for years and I have no intention of every leaving.
cons: I’ve spent the last ten minutes staring at this computer screen trying to think of a single con and I just can’t. I’ve loved working for Junior Achievement for the past few years and there isn’t a single thing I would change.

pros: Management is amazing, Tom is one of the best bosses I have ever had, and the Team I am on, we all just work so well off each other!
cons: Really not anything bad I can say about the company.

review_title: Under resourced - even for a nonprofit
pros: New President working hard to turn around an unhealthy company culture.
cons: Company leans towards micromanaging which can be a frustrating environment to work in.

pros: I have worked in a few assistant positions before coming to JA USA. None of them pay as well or treat employees as well. I have been impressed so far. The managers are very friendly and work hard to make sure you understand the job.
cons: Honestly the only one I can think of comes with the territory of working as an assistant, which is having to always be “on” when you’re at work

pros: Working here has been nothing short of wonderful! The environment, my co-workers, and the company events all make JA an absolute gem of an employer. The culture at every other company I’ve worked for doesn’t hold a candle to the one here.
cons: Not everyone is appreciative of the company culture.

pros: There are so many great things about this company including flexible schedule, constant learning, and days off. Never a dull moment. As many others commented, the people are awesome and the work week goes by quickly. Pay is good. Training provided was through. My department is cohesive.
cons: The benefits plan is below average and after all that’s happened this past year in the world an improvement to the benefits package would be a welcome change.

pros: Fairly easy job as long as you don't mind data entry. If you like spending time in schools this is the job for you.
cons: They let everyone go due to the pandemic instead of actually trying to keep all of us on. The higher ups don't care about the managers.

review_title: Beyond happy to be part of an organization that does so much good in the community
pros: I was actually on the other end of things here at JA not too long ago. The volunteers used to come into my high school to teach us about business and economics. I learned more from them than any of my teachers and that’s why I wanted to join the organization when I got the chance. I want to be part of something that’s actually making a difference in kids’ lives. So far, it’s been exactly that and I’m just beyond happy to be here.
cons: What downsides could there possibly be to working for such an altruistic organization like JA?

pros:
Wealth of knowledge at your disposal. 
Great location, and great people to work with. 
Ability to take on a range of projects and responsibilities. 
Gain useful professional skills.
cons: Upward career mobility is somewhat limited.

review_title: This place checks all my boxes
pros:
My two biggest requirements for feeling satisfied at my job are: 
(1) to feel appreciated and 
(2) to get along with my co-workers. 

Junior Achievement USA meets them both: 
(1) my hard work is always acknowledged by management and rewarded and 
(2) I work with a great team of people and all of us get along with each other, both inside and outside of work.
cons: I’m sad that some of my coworkers left. It isn’t the same without them.

pros:
Where do I even start? I have so much to say about my last 4 years with the company and I feel like I could be here all day typing away and still not cover everything. But I guess I have to start somewhere, so I’ll break things down year by year in order to better organize my thoughts.

My first year with the company was a whirlwind. I couldn’t believe how quickly things moved around here. I’d worked at a few other nonprofits before, but nothing ever really stuck because after a year or so I couldn’t see myself at any of them for the long haul. Well, my first year at JA went by so quickly that I was halfway into my second year before I even started considering whether or not I wanted to say.

In my second year I started thinking about my future with the company. I don’t believe in psychics, but my manager at the time must have the keenest interpersonal powers because it was right around this time that he called me into my office to discuss exactly that. He gave me more encouragement and praise than I’d ever received from a boss and told me that he wanted to meet together over the next few days to lay out a career path for me in the company and help me reach my full potential.

Over the course of the next week meeting with him I became more and more certain that JA was the right fit for me long-term. He didn’t just tell me what to do and how to do it, we worked together to figure out what would make me feel the most fulfilled and what my priorities were (time at home vs. salary vs. excitement vs. stability, etc.) and how I could best align my role here with those priorities. 

I’ve never given so much thought to my future in my life, and the result of it has been game-changing. I’ve been following the plan we laid out together for the past 2 years and I am EXACTLY where I want to be. I look forward to coming into work every day and I can’t express enough just how fulfilled I feel in my career. 

Suffice it to say, JA is an incredible company with a lot of potential for people who aren’t afraid of a little hard work. There are endless opportunities for growth and development if that’s what you want.
cons: I can’t see a single downside to working here. The last 4 years have been some of the most professionally rewarding of my entire career.

pros:
1-Excellent Benefits 
2-Above avg pay 
3-Promote from within 
4-Interesting work 
5-Friendly coworkers
cons:
1-Typical office politics 
2-Communication b/t departments

pros: great use of learned skills
cons: there are no cons for this internship

pros: I have been with Junior Achievement for a little over 3 years. It’s a great place to work. They don’t offer many work functions or socials, but they hold a large conference for all employees every year and that creates a real sense of solidarity among everyone.
cons: No big issues really. I believe new team members that start on could have better training. Many come in believing they could push their work on to others and do not realize this is a team effort.

review_title: I see a future for myself here
pros: The workload is manageable. The pay and benefits are excellent. Surprisingly above average pay, especially considering it’s a non-profit. Great opportunity that’s ideal for anyone just getting started in their career. I plan on staying here for the foreseeable future.
cons: I mean what’s there to complain about when you love what you do?

job_title: Operations Manager in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Junior Achievement sticks to its core values, and its loyalty to employees who put in the work is impressive. There are plenty of opportunities for team-building, which makes for terrific solidarity throughout. COVID affected operations though and I was sad to see it.
cons: I’m glad I got the opportunity to work for this company in its heyday.

pros: Great work and life balance.
cons: The position is not paid hourly. No overtime as well.

pros:
They pay people what they deserve
They have very high ethical standards
They encourage a healthy work/life balance
They are very open and communicative about expectations and priorities
cons:
Things don’t change quickly 
Working for any nonprofit is stressful

pros:
Everything we do, every decision we make, every action we take…. All of it is informed by the company’s mission. In my 4 years with the company there hasn’t been a single moment of wavering or uncertainty or talk of branching out or trying to do more or move into other areas. There isn’t the same fearfulness in our management as I’ve noticed at other non-profits I’ve worked at. They clearly aren’t operating from a place of scarcity. They know without a doubt in their minds that there’s a need for what we have to offer and that our only job is to fill that need.

Everything else is secondary, and it makes it much easier to go about the day because every decision I have to make in my role boils down to the same thing: does this align with our mission? If the answer’s no, it doesn’t matter how important it seems or how good of an idea it is, it gets nixed. It simplifies the work environment to be sure. I would even go so far as to suggest it’s the reason why this one of the least stressful non-profit jobs I’ve held in the course of my career. That and the fact that no one in management has an ego – there’s no need to kow tow or suck up to anyone to keep your job safe. 

I think the combination of both – how mission driven the company is and the way managers treat employees – is why I like working here so much and why I can see myself staying here in the long-term.
cons: There’s cons to working anywhere, and especially working at a nonprofit. There’s the usual budget constraints, limited resources, a feeling of there never being enough people to accomplish everything we want to. But that’s all par for the course. And of course, no matter where you work there are always going to be people you like working with more than others. I’m not trying to suggest that Junior Achievement is the Mary Poppins of companies (practically perfect in every way), but by comparison they’re pretty darn good and I think that should count for a lot more than it does to some people.

review_title: Don’t work here as a POC

review_title: A lot of love and a lot of passion

cons: When I decided to start a family I had to move into the private sector to do right by my family financially.

pros: Lots of talented, skilled professionals to work with. The office culture is excellent.
cons: Individual regions operate somewhat independently, which creates a disconnect between the different branches.

pros: I enjoyed my almost 4 years working for this organization. They provided a great annual conference for employees to attend. I loved the mission and had the support of many wonderful local volunteers and companies over the years.
cons: While this isn't really a con, most local markets act independently (or at least the smaller ones did while I was there). Sometimes, it felt as if we did not have a lot of support from the national office or other larger markets. Wish we would have engaged with other offices more.

pros: They do right by their employees and have a strong community presence. They’ll be around for a while.

review_title: Wouldn't wish this place on my worst enemy.
pros: Cannot think of any pros at this time.
cons: I can't imagine being treated worse in a workplace. Management belittles employees daily in a way which would never be acceptable if this organization had an HR department. They do not care about the mission, or helping kids, they just want to reach their numbers. They care even less about their employees, paying them non-livable wages and asking for more and more work every year in order to reach their goals. The "culture", or lack thereof, means that you will get berated for having a friendly conversation with a co-worker. Individuals have actually gotten reprimanded for speaking to each other. The office must remain cold, empty, and soul-sucking. The president tries to overly compensate for her flaws when first meeting someone, and seems passionate and kind. Everyone at JA knows this is a front.

job_title: Preschool Teacher in Quezon City, National Capital Region
pros: SOME fellow teachers and staff are nice
cons: Employers do not care about employees. No salary raise

review_title: Suffering from long-term leadership deficit; dysfunctional and "toxic" work environment starting from the top down.
pros: Camraderie between "worker bees" very strong
cons:
A long history of poor leadership appointments.
Management is afraid of confronting negative employee behavior from top/down. 
Board and leadership tend to be "alseep at the wheel."
Leadership not in "tune with employee needs and wants." 
Top heavy management lacks vision and communications skills.
No employee development/advancement opportunities.

review_title: JA is a Great Place to Work!
pros: JA provides a good career path, professional development while enabling an employee to make a difference in the preparation of youth.     The nature of the work requires one to step outside of a normal comfort zone and develop new skills.   From sales, to marketing, to administration to public relations.    If you like people, are professional and willing to expand your horizons, JA is a great place to work!
cons: The work is timeline driven and stressful, but rewarding.    Making sure JA volunteers get what they need from the JA experience causes staff to think of things from the volunteer's perspective.   If staff does their job correctly, the JA experience is a win-win for teacher, volunteers, JA staff and students!

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Worth, TX
pros: Great program for students. You will meet some amazing people (teacher's, students and company coordinators)
cons: Under paid.  Rude front office staff.  Unorganized.  Lack of funding do to horrible management and racist leadership.  Office President has no idea what he's doing.  You may be out of a job not too long after you start do to lack of funding caused by the President.  President is not good with people. He takes on extra tasks and give them to over worked employees.  You will not be acknowledged for your hard work.  DO NOT APPLY IF YOU ARE AFRICAN AMERICAN. You will be not be given an equal work opportunity.  You will be over looked when it comes to taking on projects.  You can do your best and have no complainants however you will still not be up to par for him.

review_title: POCs - Don't Waste Your Time Working Here!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Company pension plan.  Serves high need schools, but program quality is an issue.
cons: Leadership lacks credibility. Most of them are dialing it in so that they can grow their pension dollars.  Look closely at leadership and you find a network of old, white risk-averse men., and "Handmaiden-like" women. They lack imagination and the ability to scale this organization. JA is constantly treading water, trying to survive.  Stay away from this organization if you are a person of color. You cannot build a career there. You will never rise to the top leadership positions. Their annual employee conferences look like the Republican Convention - a sea of whiteness - with a few spots of brown. White privilege is the norm in JA - with a top-down, out-of-touch management style. POC talent works twice as hard to get half the benefits and recognition. The limitations of JA leadership at the local and national levels is well known to employees. There are better financial literacy and entrepreneurship education organizations out there doing much more exciting and cutting-edge work.

pros: JA has a really wonderful, important mission. JA Rocky Mountain was a leader in programs compared to other JA offices.
cons: JA Rocky Mountain does not have a competitive wage, even in the non profit industry. They advertise generous benefits to new and potential employees, but frown upon your use of said “generous” benefits (example: PTO and Maternity Leave). During my tenure at JA Rocky Mountain, I saw record high turnover for their office, and unprofessional and unethical behavior from the CEO. The CEO gives the impression she wants a progressive and competitive organization, but never actually makes steps toward such. Additionally, they offer no room for professional growth, thus leaving employees no choice but to move on to other organizations.

review_title: Great goals & curriculum to help students prepare the world of work.
pros: Helping students - mission. Excellent curriculum. Has potential if reorganized with professional, creative thought leaders, visionaries. Many part time positions nice for parents with young children or people not working for income. Nice organization for recent grads.  Many managers & directors don't have college degrees.
cons: Inconsistent management and policies between districts.  No teamwork.  No chance of training, minimal chance of career advancement.  Outdated rules/structure. Low pay even for non profits. Districts, states, nation territorial in regard to fundraising. Not as flexible as it would seem or as advertised.

review_title: Great for kids but not for employees
job_title: Program Assistant in Coconut Creek, FL
pros: The children in the 5th grade program are so sweet. It is hard but if you are a fast paced person you can spend so much time teaching children useful information. DO NOT work here if you are a slow person or easily overwhelmed. There are days with a lot of children and close to no volunteers. Volunteers can also be very nasty.
cons: The one in south Florida was very mismanaged. Typical middle aged women that are so bored they live for drama and I don’t so it didn’t work out. If they get new management it would be great.

pros:
Good mission to educate students valuable lessons and curriculum
Ability to manage contacts and develop new partnerships
Children look up to you and provide feedback right away
cons:
Low pay
No true HR department
Demanding job - to reach your goals you need to spend more time than the "37.5 hour work week" we are supposed to have
It is all a numbers game, the children and quality of programming are not the priority
No room for growth, only steps are Senior Operations Manager and Director
Promotions are based solely on tenure, not achievement

pros:
It is very easy to see the immediate benefit of JA programming for youth.  There is no doubt that they are fulfilling a need and creating perspective.  Teachers trust the brand so it is an easy sell.  

Ability to network with many schools and make connections in many corporate environments, all while making a great impact.
cons:
Management at my location was quite disorganized at times, but the people have since changed. Connections still with the organization are pleased, and they are executing on a lot of good ideas.

Sometimes new volunteers have a lot of questions or get caught up in the details before they actually perform their teaching in the classroom.  

Pay was super low.

review_title: Stay far away From JA OF WASHINGTON
pros: Bringing valuable programs to k-12
cons: Inexperienced leadership. Autocratic, lack of resources, transactional leadership style, bottom line focus, punitive, vindictive and disrespectful to employees.  Do as I say management. If you don’t perform in a short period of time, you are out.  Never got a raise in three years.

pros: The mission is good -- they fill a gap that should be handled by the public schools.  The volunteers learn to respect the work of educators by being in the classroom themselves.  Lower level employees are great to work with.
cons: Management of the Pittsburgh office is awful.  Director is rarely present, leaving lower level staff to manage things themselves.  There's a lot of turnover due to low pay, the promotion of people based on office politics rather than performance, and a lot of negative energy.

review_title: Rewarding for its mission and frustrating for my experience in my location
pros: Great work-life balance and latitude to take on various projects.  Always flexible regarding personal needs as long as work is finished.
cons: Not all of my colleagues treat working at JA as a career.  Several of them are not just resistant to making an effort to improve, but openly resist any efforts to make things better for everyone.

review_title: Great career if you're comfortable with a less than teacher salary
pros:
-It's a nonprofit focused on inspiring youth, so you get to feel great about working for such a powerful mission 
-Networking! From Board members to business leaders in the community to teachers and students, you get to meet and interact with a variety of different people. 
-JA is a well recognized brand. 
-Health insurance 100 percent employer paid (although it's not the most competitive coverage on the market, but, it saves you $$$ each year). 
-Depending on the area you work in, your office environment and management, you could have some flexibility, especially on the programs side. You work hard to achieve goals, but, remote work and flexible hours could be available. 
-Great resume builder especially for someone starting our their career.
cons:
-It's a very sales-disguised business. Just like with sales, you have quotas and yearly goals to achieve. Except unlike sales, you don't get commission or bonuses. If you're a program manager not only are you recruiting volunteers, inputting data on a daily basis, pitching program and fundraising sales and prospecting, you're also managing your board, recruiting teachers and schools, seeking funding (even though there is an entire additional development department who gets paid to do that job specifically) and planning and assisting with all types of events. 
-The mission of "it's for the kids" gets lost and quality of programming diminishes because the focus is always on numbers. It's a numbers game with this nonprofit. 
-Hours can be long and are sometimes non-traditional (i.e. attending evening Board meetings or working 15+ hours into the night at a fundraising event/working on a Saturday- rare but does happen).
-After about two years, the same repetitive work doesn't feel intellectually fulfilling anymore, especially when your salary stays the same. 
-Program / funding goals can be challenging to achieve especially as school districts go through changes, people's volunteer and giving efforts shift, and companies just don't have the funding anymore or have other nonprofits they align their CSR strategies with. It's very competitive being in nonprofit world.

review_title: Good Place to Start Your Career
pros: Trying their best to help children learn about the real-world and how to be prepared for the workforce, Many great events and hard working people. This job helped open the doors to many great opportunities because it helped start my professional network. Even though I am not working there anymore, I still love the nonprofits mission and volunteer at events when I can!!
cons: Of course as a nonprofit the salary is low, but if you love that work you are doing money isn't everything. This is a great place to start your career.

pros: Great mission, fun working in Biz Town, working with other employees who really care, loved working with students, educators and volunteers, decent work-life balance,
cons: Poor management that is unwilling or unable to solve problems, lots of finger pointing and no viable solutions offered when issues arise,  management that is dishonest and rude to their employees, no growth opportunities, small company, low morale due to several quality individuals leaving and being replaced by less-qualified employees,

pros: Access to a great set of resources, especially for a non-profit. The HQ is well organized and has great talent. Employees are well versed in the mission and genuinely believe in what it accomplishes.  They were generous with sick time, paid holidays and vacation time.
cons: Local offices are disconnected with HQ, very numbers driven organization and quality of programming is overlooked. Difficult to work without access to the latest technology to accomplish goals. Although the organization is large, individual chapters are run with lack of experience and professionalism in the work place.

review_title: Washington state is extremely disorganized! Run far away
job_title: Accounts Payable Specialist in Auburn, WA
pros: Coworkers overall were nice and genuinely wanted to help. Commute was easy. Honestly can't think of anything else positive to say.
cons: No guidance for new hires. Unrealistic job expectations. Nonprofit means when things aren't working they don't get fixed for a long time. Management very poor, always in a financial crisis. Cramped cubicle that I had to share with 5 other people. Worked overtime on a weekend for 10 hours with no breaks. I was hired and it took 3 weeks for them to set up my computer. I was promised potential full time and raise and instead I was suddenly let go after 3 months of struggle over "budget constraints". miserable

review_title: Junior Achievement is dedicated to inspiring and preparing young people to succeed in a global economy.
job_title: Vice President of Development in Walnut Creek, CA
pros: mission driven, great people and excellent cause that addresses today's issues. Lots of flexibility in schedule, leadership helps develop clear objectives. You get to experience a wide variety of industries and people. You get to deliver on the mission by personally  teaching in a classroom.
cons: work/life balance can be difficult to maintain; numbers over impact, mission can be difficult to provide clear ROI to corporate donors, national org needs to catch up to other large NPs with a national awareness campaign.

pros: Decent pay. You are paired for weekend work and for all mileage. You have annual bonuses based on performance. And there are lots of company events which are great for networking. Good benefits.
cons: It is a lot of work. Like a ton of work. Customer service is a large part of the job and you will deal with a lot of rude people. Not a lot of room to move around. Sometimes you will have 12 hour work days.

review_title: I have had the opportunity to work with great people and have made amazing friendships!
pros: Autonomy with schedule. Great networking opportunities. Meet some great kids. Work with great teachers and administrators! Opportunity to showcase talents with special projects.
cons: There is little no room for lateral growth. Turn-over is high and pay is not competitive to cost of living.

review_title: Great starting out job, but not for long term
pros:
- when students are getting a quality experience and JA makes a difference 
-relatively flexible hours
- great insurance options
cons:
-emphasis on meeting numbers and not providing quality interactions
-long hours in order to meet the needs of companies that are volunteering 
-weekends occasionally
- no bonuses, no incentives, no extra perks
- little to no opportunities to move up
- there are professional development opportunities, but they cost your area office money.
- no money for volunteer appreciation events

pros: The mission of JA is outstanding: to serve students with skills in financial literacy, workforce readiness and entrepreneurship.  The programmatic work is fast paced and very rewarding.
cons: Leadership seems to turn around every 2-3 years or so. Significant change in direction and shift in priorities with such frequency can lead to stress and confusion within the small team. Small in size, this non profit does not offer much in the way of promotion opportunities.

review_title: Lovely Job but the pay sucks and no room for advancement
pros: Its very relaxed , the environment is great,
cons: the coworkers don't want you to learn anything new due to job security issues. Yo will not learn FP OR BT if your a front desk worker.

review_title: Great vision that gets lost in numbers
pros:
Great company vision... wonderful resume builder
Make a ton of contacts
cons: Low low pay, way way too much work. Demands of reaching goals feels more important than the actual impact of programs.

pros: The staff is incredibly dedicated to their work, they spend so much of their time providing the most perfect experience for students, parents, and teachers in the area. They are friendly, kind, and giving people. They do amazing work for their community by impacting kids in a way that will hopefully stay with them for the rest of their lives!
cons: Sometimes you find that some parent volunteers are less attentive than their fifth grade students!

review_title: JA of AZ is a good place for those starting their careers, but not for highly intelligent, creative experienced people
job_title: Senior Director of Development in Tempe, AZ
pros: For a nonprofit, it has good salaries for its top fundraisers with good benefits. Employees are fun and friendly.
cons: Poor salaries for program staff. Very rigid environment with no out of the box thinking. Little cooperation among fundraising staff.

review_title: Proud to work for a good cause but disappointed with the management structure & system
pros: You get  to be a part of helping kids learn how to be financially intelligent and responsible using fun lesson plans.
cons: The management structure is built on the corporate model rather than typical non-profit model.  Doesn't feel like a team environment.

review_title:
JA NY - great people who care about kids

It was, for the most part, a good place to work.
job_title: Vice President of Development in New York, NY
pros:
Part of a terrific organization
Working to benefit the lives of local children

JA rides the line between traditional nonprofit and corporate work, and enabled me to grow significantly in my knowledge and understanding of both work worlds.
cons:
Divided office - program team and development team don't work as closely as they should.  
Finger pointing between teams.

pros: Wonderful Mission, Great people to work with. Great relationships with community partners.
cons:
Very low pay.  Segregated work environment (the development staff do not engage with other staff in the office unless they need us to be present for fundraisers).
Absolutely no room for growth.  Upper and Middle Management has worked here for 1-+ years.

pros: Great mission and great having a national network to tap into
cons: Poor management with lack of experience managing employees, lack of diversity among staff and board, no real solutions when issues are brought up, too many ideas without the resources to execute them, no defined job descriptions, can't retain a team long enough to add value, no growth opportunities, low salary, no work-life balance/expected to work 24 hours a day, passive-aggressive behavior from manager(s)

pros: Potential donors and volunteers in mid and west Michigan are very eager for the mission JA provides, so gaining support is not difficult. The company allows staff to develop and manage their own relationships and is receptive to new strategies. There is a lot of untapped potential, and unlike many non-profits, the organization is growing rather than shrinking.
cons: The pay is comparatively low.

pros: Working for JA provides a wonderful opportunity to help students in elementary, middle and high school manage their career and financial futures.
cons: Development challenges keep salaries low. The work flow and expectations do not seem to be evenly distributed around the organization.

pros: It was a great experience going around and teaching young students about different areas of government and basic finance.
cons: My manager said that I would be working 20 hours a week, which in reality turned out to be an average of 4 or 5 a week.

pros: The program is a super hands-on learning experience, which is great for kids. They get to work with volunteers from all walks of life, which allows them to learn about different career opportunities. The curriculum they are taught in class, and on-site, is fundamental to their overall financial success. They offer bonuses, and the insurance is decent.
cons: Super long work hours, expect to work 50+ hours a week with no overtime pay. You will do so much more than your job actually requires, for example: calling schools, multiple volunteer trainings a week, cleaning, shipping, mandatory "volunteer" events outside of work hours (which are unpaid), obligatory company donations, and a plethora of other things. They are 100% understaffed which puts an additional amount of strain on employees. The money you make is a joke; anyone who works in this position should make double what they offer. Also, favoritism plays a HUGE part advancement, they could care less about performance or seniority.

review_title: Junior Achievement of Idaho is terrific
pros: Great staff, especially the President that joined JA Idaho one year ago and who is really taking us to new heights.  Great leadership and a dedicated team that helps so many of our youth in Idaho.
cons: I only wish the new President of Junior Achievement of Idaho had come along sooner

pros: The mission is admirable. You will see a marked change in the attitude of the students as they begin to contemplate life after graduation from high school.
cons: Office politics as usual.The executive team were in it financially for themselves. They are now gone after many attempts by staff over 5 years to have them exposed.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Walnut Creek, CA
pros: The JA mission is honorable and impactful. The students served and volunteers recruited are inspiring to work with and the staff is hardworking
cons: Senior Leadership lacks vision, voice and the support structure to maintain staff and constituents. Office environment is ego driven and authority is based on tenure and not performance

job_title: Senior Executive Assistant in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: It became a family.  The culture was of caring, kindness, and the goal was to educate young people before diving into the world of business.
cons: I honestly cannot think of one.  I loved working there, and loved the people. Not a bad apple in the bunch.

review_title: Potential to be a fun job
job_title: Operations Manager At JA Chicago in Chicago, IL
pros: Mission of company is critical for today's youth.  Work with some great people internally. Great work/life balance.
cons: This review is only specific to Chicago chapter.  Very high turn over. Management does not listen to employees suggestions to make job successful. Too many accountabilities to do the job well.

pros: Great training, pay and benefits for the industry. Most things are handled at a local level, so it doesn't feel like a huge organization. They promote from within.
cons: Dealing with anything on the national level is a pain. Kinda stuck in their ways and not open to suggestions for improvement.

pros: Great team, values work / home life balance, wonderful perks and PTO, organizations that want to see their employees grow internally.
cons: Pay.  If you work for a nonprofit then this should be no surprise.  You have to value the mission.  Pros definitely outweigh the cons.

pros: Flexible hours, good benefits, fun environment, meet new people often, lots of networking opportunities
cons: Some weekend work due to benefits/banquets/fundraising events, some travel required to events and volunteer trainings

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Coconut Creek, FL
pros: Most employee place mission first. Great programs and great vision for increasing community impact.
cons: New leadership still trying to find its way, unify team. Mistrust and lack of communication amongst team members.

review_title: Excellent leadership who are transforming the organization

cons: As a franchise organization there are discrepancies between area offices.

review_title: Poor  Upper Management at JA Chicago
pros: Great educational mission and company supporters
cons: Extremely high turnover and poor compensation. Metrics driven above all else - but worst is the exec. level management staff. Talk about change but never implement, incompetent & most in their roles over 20 years! EXTREMELY POOR COMMUNICATION on all levels. No appreciation or support for staff. No training - you are on your own.

review_title: As a Campus Coordinator, I recruited class members, assisted lecturers (managers) in the class.
pros: Very resourceful. You have many chances to meet great people from big companies who are willing to share ideas with you.
cons: Sometimes a little inflexible but on the whole it is flexible.

pros: Some employees are very focused and driven to succeed. Programs are developed through national organization and have been around for 100 years.
cons: CEO is a micromanager who instills distrust in employees by bad mouthing them to others in the guise of "you'll need to watch out for". Over 15 of the 23 member staff have left in just over a year and multiple positions have been turned over more than once.

pros: You get a nice polo

pros: Great mission and great connections. You get a chance to work with all different types of people from educators to business people

review_title: Driven by quantity over quality diminishing program effectiveness.
